title: Holcombe Hill and Moor Walking Route

nearby.description: Whalley Abbey and the River Calder

images.title: Paul Anderson / Holcombe Village
images.caption: Holcombe Village. The village of Holcombe is in the middle of all the trees with Emmanuel Church on the right. The village occupies a picturesque position on the slopes of Holcombe Hill. The buildings in the area are predominantly made up of stone cottages a public house, a restaurant, church and primary school. At one time the village also boasted a shop, post office, and a regular bus service linking it to Holcombe Brook, a neighbouring village in the valley bottom one mile to the south. The main road to the left is Helmshore Road with the sign on wall of Shoulder of Mutton pub in the foreground.

images.title: Paul Anderson / Emmanuel Church Holcombe
images.caption: Emmanuel Church Holcombe. Built in 1853 the imposing stone spire of the church can be seen from miles around because of its elevated location on the lower slopes of Holcombe Hill.

images.title: Paul Anderson / CC BY-SA (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0)
images.caption: The Shoulder of Mutton pub in Helmshore Road, Holcombe. The pub was built in the late 18th century and is a Grade II listed building.

images.title: Paul Anderson / Chapel Lane Holcombe
images.caption: Chapel Lane Holcombe. These stone built cottages date from the early part of the 1800s.

images.title: John Darch / Peel Tower on Holcombe Moor
images.caption: Peel Tower on Holcombe Moor

images.title: Kevan Corr / Holcombe Moor NT sign
images.caption: Holcombe Moor NT sign. There is a dog's waterproof jacket fastened to the post this sign is on.

images.title: Peter Worrell / The  "Pilgrim's Cross" Holcombe
images.caption: The "Pilgrim's Cross" Holcombe A wayside cross stood on this site from at least 1176 marking the route from Manchester to Whalley Abbey. In 1901 only the base remained and that was broken up by unknown hands. The vicar of Holombe, Rev. H. Dowsett was instrumental in starting a public collection which resulted in the memorial stone being erected in 1902. Another cross on the same route was at Holden, Haslingden

images.title: Paul Anderson / Holcombe Village School
images.caption: Holcombe Village School. The Emmanuel Holcomde Church Of England Primary School ,as known by its proper title, was built in 1864. The first major change to the building was in 1964 when offices,staffroom and toilets were added.

description: A circular walk around Holcombe Moor visiting Peel Tower on the way. The moorland is owned by the National Trust and a popular place for walkers, cyclists and bird watchers. The walk starts from the public car park in the village of Holcombe on Lumb Carr Road. From here it is a short walk up to Peel Tower, just to the north east. The tower is dedicated to Sir Robert Peel, the 19th century Prime Minister considered the father of modern British policing. There are fabulous over the surrounding area from the elevated position of the tower. The route then follows a footpath north to the Pilgrim's Cross. This notable landmark includes a cubed shaped monument whose sides tell the story and history of the cross. It dates all the way back to A.D. 1176 and was the site where Pilgrims to Whalley Abbey prayed and rested. After examining the cross the route continues north towards Beetle Hill. Here you turn east along a section of the Rossendale Way before picking up a bridleway track to take you back to Holcombe.
